Overall, "The Lovely Bones" is a complex and thought-provoking film that, while not perfect, offers a unique and haunting take on the story of a murdered girl and her family's journey towards healing.

NASA has announced the renaming of its upcoming sun-studying mission, the Parker Solar Probe, in honor of pioneering astrophysicist Eugene Parker who predicted the existence of the solar wind in 1958. The mission, which is scheduled to launch in July 2018, will come closer to the sun than any spacecraft in history, performing 24 close flybys of the sun and bringing it within just 3.9 million miles of the solar surface. The probe will be equipped with a 7.5-foot-wide heat shield made of advanced carbon-composite material and will carry a chip loaded with photographs of Parker and his seminal solar-wind paper.

The Parker Solar Probe aims to answer two long-standing puzzles: how is the solar wind accelerated, and why is the sun's outer atmosphere, known as the corona, so much hotter than the solar surface? Understanding these questions is crucial as solar storms can cause significant damage to satellites and power supplies, with estimates suggesting that a major solar event could cause $2 trillion in damage in the U.S. alone.

The mission will carry four science instruments to measure the sun's electric and magnetic fields, photograph solar structure, and study the solar wind. The observations and data could provide insight into the physics of stars, change what we know about the corona, increase understanding of solar wind, and help improve forecasting of major space weather events.

The Parker Solar Probe will be the first mission to the sun and its outermost atmosphere, called the corona. It will have to withstand extreme heat and radiation, making it a historic and challenging mission. NASA has invited Parker to come up with an inscription for a plate that will be installed on the spacecraft.

The probe's objectives include tracing the flow of energy that heats and accelerates the sun's corona and solar wind, determining the structure and dynamics of the plasma and magnetic fields at the sources of the solar wind, and exploring mechanisms that accelerate and transport energetic particles.

Two major data breaches at Neiman Marcus and Target during the holiday season have raised concerns over the security of customers' personal and financial information. Neiman Marcus' network was penetrated as early as July, but the breach was not fully contained until mid-January. The company disclosed the data theft in late December, stating that some customers' payment cards had been used fraudulently after purchases at their stores. Neiman Marcus apologized for the delay in disclosure and defended its decision, stating that it waited to confirm evidence before making an announcement.

Target, on the other hand, reported a data breach in mid-December, affecting approximately 40 million credit and debit card accounts and potentially impacting another 70 million people with personal information. The breach was caused by a type of malware that targeted the point-of-sale systems, allowing the hackers to access unencrypted data during the authorization stage. The malware, which is new to eCrime, is believed to have originated from Eastern Europe.

A report from computer firm iSight, filed to the U.S. Secret Service and obtained by NBC News, provides insight into the Target breach. The report details the sophisticated nature of the attack and the regions where the software capabilities exist to create such malware. The operational sophistication of the hackers is highlighted in the report, which notes that memory scraping capabilities have been available in the Russian-language underground for some time.

Both investigations are ongoing, and a growing group of state attorneys general are jointly investigating both breaches to determine if they are related. The authorities are examining whether the attacks are connected, as both appear to have been committed by criminal groups in Eastern Europe.

Cardholders can expect more of these types of breaches in the future, as the potential rewards for cyber crooks are high with little risk involved. Both Neiman Marcus and Target have offered free credit monitoring to affected customers.

The discovery of the lead tube reliquary is significant because there are only 43 known lead tubes from this time period in the entire world, and most of them contain holy water rather than ashes. The Bulgarian archaeologists believe that a pilgrim from the fortress of Poros went on a pilgrimage to the grave of St. John the Theologian in Ephesus and brought the reliquary back as a holy possession.

The Senate Commerce Committee released a report on the data industry, revealing that major data companies collectively own vast consumer profiles and sell deeply personal information, sometimes to identity thieves. The companies, including Acxiom, Experian, and Epsilon, were queried by the Committee and invited testimony from privacy groups. The report found that some companies, like Equifax, were cooperative, while others, such as Acxiom, Experian, and Epsilon, refused to explain how they collected their data or who they were selling it to, citing confidentiality clauses.

Experian was found to have sold personal information, including social security numbers and banking information, to an alleged online identity theft ring. The same subsidiary, Court Ventures, also appeared on a list of companies that requested private information about gun permit holders in Virginia.

The data collected includes sensitive information like whether a consumer has certain health conditions, how many doctor visits they've had, and even how many whiskey drinks they consumed in the past 30 days. This data is then sorted into a dictionary with over 75,000 data points. Privacy groups testified that the companies also sell lists of rape victims and people with HIV and AIDS.

The World Privacy Forum discovered similar lists while investigating how data brokers collect and sell consumer information. Marketers buy this data to target shoppers based on their income, clothing size, and other personal information. Other lists included the home addresses of police officers, a mailing list for domestic violence shelters, and a list of people with addictive behaviors towards drug and alcohol.

The mere existence of these lists highlights the need for increased government regulations, as data brokers are currently only required by federal law to maintain the privacy of a consumer's data if it is used for credit, employment, insurance, or housing. Medical privacy laws prohibit doctors from sharing patient information, but medical information that data brokers get elsewhere is fair game.

Some data brokers offer ways to opt out, but many have unclear opt-out procedures or none at all. Plus, most consumers have no idea they're on the lists in the first place. The Senate committee investigated the $156 billion data brokerage industry for a year, and the Federal Trade Commission has also called on major data brokers to increase transparency into their data practices.

A new study published in The New England Journal of Medicine suggests that for individuals with coronary artery disease, rapidly losing and regaining weight, or "yo-yo" dieting, may significantly increase the risk for deadly heart attacks, strokes, and even death. The study, which was sponsored by Pfizer and led by Dr. Sripal Bangalore of the New York University School of Medicine, followed 9,509 men and women with stable coronary artery disease over five years, recording their weight an average of 12 times. The researchers found that those with the highest weight variability had a 78 percent higher risk of new onset diabetes, a 117 percent higher risk of heart attack, a 136 percent higher risk of stroke, and a 124 percent higher risk of death compared to those with the lowest weight variability.

Coronary artery disease develops when the major blood vessels that supply the heart become damaged or diseased, often due to cholesterol-containing deposits and inflammation. This narrowing of the coronary arteries decreases blood flow to the heart, potentially causing chest pain, shortness of breath, or other symptoms. Prevention and treatment involve a healthy lifestyle.

Previous research has linked yo-yo dieting to increased risk of poor heart health. However, new research indicates that the health consequences may be even more severe for individuals with pre-existing coronary heart disease. In a study of 9,509 men and women with coronary heart disease, those who experienced large fluctuations in weight over an average of 4.7 years were at much higher risk of heart attack, stroke, and death than those who experienced little change in body weight. The largest weight fluctuations were linked to 117 percent more heart attacks, 124 percent more deaths, and 136 percent more strokes.

The study, led by Dr. Sripal Bangalore, found that yo-yo dieting, or weight cycling, is defined as repeated cycles of weight loss and weight gain. Numerous studies have documented the possible health risks of yo-yo dieting, including a greater risk of death from heart disease. The new research from Dr. Bangalore and colleagues builds on these findings, revealing how yo-yo dieting may impact the health of individuals who have pre-existing coronary heart disease.

A three-year-old girl named Finley Puleo Boyle from Kailua, Hawaii, died following a dental procedure at Island Dentistry for Children in December 2013. According to autopsy reports and news sources, Finley suffered a heart attack during the procedure, which was attributed to the sedatives and local anesthesia administered to her. The medical examiner, Dr. Christopher Happy, classified the death as an accident.

Finley had gone to the dentist to receive cavity fillings and root canals. During the procedure, she was given a combination of sedatives, including Demerol, hydroxyzine, and chlorohydrate, as well as laughing gas and a local anesthetic, lidocaine with epinephrine. Immediately following the lidocaine injection, Finley became unresponsive and went into cardiopulmonary arrest.

Finley's parents, Ashley and Evan Boyle, filed a negligence lawsuit against the dentist, Dr. Lilly Geyer, while their daughter was still in a coma. The lawsuit alleges that Finley was not monitored properly during the procedure, and that oxygen levels were not checked every five minutes as required. Instead, they went unchecked for 26 minutes. The lawsuit also states that no CPR was administered when Finley went into cardiac arrest, and that someone had to fetch a doctor from another office.

Geyer's attorney, John Nishimoto, has declined to comment on the allegations due to the ongoing lawsuit. He did not respond to requests for comment on the autopsy report. Geyer was issued a license to practice dentistry in Hawaii in July 2005, and as of last December, there were no records of complaints against her or her practice on file with the Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs.

In response to the incident, new state rules took effect in January 2014, tightening oversight of dental sedation in Hawaii. The details of the incident are still under investigation, and no criminal charges have been brought against Geyer at this time.

Caleb had been living with his grandparents during his time away from his mother and had gained weight. Markham expressed her satisfaction with her son's progress on the soy formula and hoped that the criminal case against her would be dropped.

In a separate incident, a vegan mother in Seminole County, Florida, named Sarah Markham, had her newborn son, Caleb, returned to her custody after several months. Markham had been arrested in June when her son was less than two weeks old due to concerns about his weight loss. She wanted to supplement her breast milk with vegan formula instead of taking her child to the hospital as ordered by a doctor. The judge ultimately determined that there was no evidence of abuse or neglect and threw out the child protective services' claim against Markham. Her attorney, Mark O'Mara, expected the criminal case against her to be dismissed as well. A new study published in the journal Cancer reveals that one in seven colon and rectal cancer cases in the U.S. are diagnosed in patients younger than age 50, despite guidelines recommending screenings begin at 50. The research, led by Dr. Samantha Hendren of the University of Michigan, found that younger patients were more likely to have advanced stage cancer but lived slightly longer without a recurrence due to aggressive treatment. The study is a wake-up call to the medical community, as colorectal cancer has traditionally been viewed as a disease of the elderly.

The analysis of cancer registry data from 1998 to 2011 showed that nearly 15 percent of the 258,000 patients with colorectal tumors were diagnosed before age 50. Younger patients were 30 percent more likely to have tumors that had spread to the lymph nodes and 50 percent more likely to have cancer that had advanced to other organs.

Despite having more aggressive disease, younger patients had slightly better outcomes. Five-year survival odds were about 95 percent for patients under 50 diagnosed with local tumors, compared to roughly 92 percent for older people. With tumors that spread to the lymph nodes, five-year survival rates were 76 percent for young people and 70 percent for older patients, while with cancers that metastasized to other organs the survival odds were 21 percent versus 14 percent, respectively.

The study also highlighted the importance of recognizing symptoms such as bleeding, changes in bowel habits, or pain when going to the bathroom, which can point to the need for diagnostic screening. However, these symptoms are often ignored or ascribed to other conditions.

Doctors should be on the lookout for these warning signs and consider screening for people with a family history of colon cancer or other risk factors at an earlier age than 50. It's unclear whether changing preventive screening guidelines to start at a younger age would ultimately prevent more cancer deaths, and more research is needed to understand the implications.

A significant archaeological discovery in a rock shelter in the Flinders Ranges of South Australia has revealed evidence of human settlement dating back 49,000 years. The site, known as Warratyi, was discovered by archaeologist Giles Hamm and local Adnyamathanha elder Clifford Coulthard during a survey. The discovery includes artefacts such as bone and quartz tools, red ochre, and gypsum pigments, which are the earliest known use of these materials in Australia.

The findings challenge previous assumptions that Indigenous Australians were not as innovative as similar populations elsewhere in the world. The site also contains evidence of human interaction with megafauna, including bones from a giant wombat-like Diprotodon optatum and eggs from an ancient giant bird.

The discovery pushes back the earliest known dates for the development of key technologies such as bone needles, wood-handled stone tools, and hafted axe technology. The site also provides the first reliably dated evidence of human interaction with megafauna in Australia.

The Warratyi site is significant because it is located more than 2,000 km from the early settlement of Lake Mungo in southeastern New South Wales, making it a much more difficult trek for early humans. The tools have been dated using a couple of estimates, with quartz grains from the site dating to 44,000 years ago, and radiocarbon dating of burnt eggshells revealing them to be between 45,000 and 49,000 years old.

The discovery has been met with controversy, as another site, Carpenter's Gap in the Kimberley region of northwest Australia, has also produced a tiny axe fragment dated to around the same time period. However, the methodology of the Warratyi study is considered to be as good as it gets, and it is a very important site and a significant find.

The discovery of Warratyi provides real evidence of the widespread presence of Indigenous Australians within just 1,000 years of hitting the coast and challenges the Eurocentric view that material culture in Australia is simplistic and backward. The study has been published in Nature.

Previously, Spectacles were only available through vending machines, which popped up in major metro areas around the country, and a store in Manhattan. Due to high demand and limited supply, those who managed to get a pair could resell them for thousands of dollars.

The glasses, which allow wearers to take circular videos and post them to their Snapchat accounts, are now available for $129.99 in the U.S. Buyers should expect to wait two to four weeks for their Spectacles to ship, and households are limited to six pairs. Snap has also stopped selling charging cases and cords on Amazon.

Snap is making Spectacles more widely available to prove to investors that they can generate revenue for the business, not just be a brand stunt. The company lost $514.6 million last year and will need to sell approximately 4 million pairs of Spectacles to break even this year. In July 1967, Detroit experienced a violent riot that left 43 people dead, nearly 1,200 injured, and 7,200 arrested. The incident at the Algiers Motel, where three unarmed black men were killed by police, is a notorious example of white police brutality during this time. Kathryn Bigelow's new film, "Detroit," revisits this event, mixing fact with fiction to create a visceral and harrowing portrayal of the night.

Bigelow's career took a hit with her 1999 film "Strange Days," which dealt with the murder of a black hip-hop artist by white Los Angeles cops. However, she bounced back with the Academy Award-winning films "The Hurt Locker" and "Zero Dark Thirty." With "Detroit," she chose to make a historical drama about the Algiers Motel incident, which has been the subject of controversy and debate.

The film opens with a brief history of the mass movement of African-Americans from the rural south to the urban north and west after World War I, leading to a majority-black city with a majority-white police force. The early scenes depict the tense climate between the police and citizens, culminating in a riot that forces the evacuation of a revue where The Dramatics were set to perform. Reed (Algee Smith) and Fred Temple (Jacob Latimore) make the fateful decision to wait out the curfew at the Algiers Motel.

The centerpiece of the film is the police occupation of the Algiers, which Bigelow depicts in graphic detail. The night is a horrifying experience for the guests, who are subjected to intimidation, torture, and murder by the police. The film raises questions about the functioning-as-designed armature of an inherently racist justice system, as the tactics used by the officers' lawyer to discredit the prosecution's witnesses are familiar and infuriating.

Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla, shocked the market last week when he announced on Twitter that he was considering taking the electric car maker private at a price of $420 per share. The proposed deal, which would value Tesla at over $70 billion before debt, would be the largest buyout in history. Following Musk's tweet, several independent directors of Tesla's board confirmed that they had met several times over the past week to discuss Musk's proposal.

The board members, who included Brad Buss, Robyn Denholm, Ira Ehrenpreis, Antonio Gracias, Linda Johnson Rice, and James Murdoch, issued a statement acknowledging that Musk had opened a discussion about taking the company private and addressing the funding for such a bid. However, the statement left open the question of whether the board was satisfied that Musk had secured the necessary funding.

Two board members, venture capitalist Steve Jurvetson and Musk's brother Kimbal Musk, did not sign onto the statement. Jurvetson has taken leave from Tesla following accusations of sexual harassment. The board's statement also raised questions about the timing of the announcement, as it came after Tesla had filed its 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission but before the information was disclosed to the public.

Musk's announcement caused wild swings in Tesla's stock price, with shares reaching a peak of $368 after the tweets before trading was halted. Trading resumed later in the day, and Tesla shares surged close to their all-time high of $385. However, the deal's structure and financing remain ambiguous, and regulators are likely to be interested in the evidence supporting Musk's claim that funding was secured.

Some experts have raised concerns about the irregularity of Musk's announcement via Twitter and the potential motives behind it, such as influencing the stock price. Tesla is the most shorted stock in the history of the market, and those traders are likely to have lost money when the share price rose on the announcement. The deal's success would also depend on Musk's ability to raise the necessary financing for a cash-flow negative company.

In the realm of space exploration and the search for intelligent alien civilizations, several intriguing theories and discoveries have emerged. One such theory, proposed by Russian astronomer Nikolai Kardashev in 1962, outlines the three stages of galactic expansion for technologically advanced civilizations, known as Type I, II, and III. Type I civilizations harness all the resources of a planet, Type II civilizations utilize all the radiation of a star, and Type III civilizations control all the resources of a galaxy.

Recently, a new paper by Dan Hooper, a senior scientist at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory and a professor of astronomy and astrophysics at the University of Chicago, has revived Kardashev's model and added an apocalyptic twist. Hooper argues that harvesting energy from distant stars is not only the best way to increase a civilization's available resources but also the only way to prevent the ever-expanding universe from leaving that civilization isolated in the vastness of space.

The presence of dark energy, which is causing the universe to expand at an accelerating rate, means that stars beyond our Local Group will fall beyond the cosmic horizon, becoming unobservable and inaccessible. This poses a challenge for humans and any other civilizations seeking to meet aliens in distant galaxies, as they will need to capture and harvest stars from other galaxies before they become inaccessible forever.

To accomplish this, scientists and science-fiction authors have proposed the use of Dyson spheres, colossal structures made of millions of solar-powered satellites that can hover around a star and beam its energy back to a nearby planet. This idea was first proposed by Freeman Dyson in a scientific paper in 1960 and later popularized in science fiction.

Ancient extraterrestrial civilizations, millions of years older than humanity, would need enormous amounts of energy, making Dyson spheres an attractive solution. However, creating such structures would require more material than all the planets of a solar system could provide. Instead, practical Dyson spheres would be made from millions of individual solar-collecting satellites, forming a cloud around the star.

North and South Korea have made diplomatic strides in recent days, with plans to march together under a unified flag and form a joint women's ice hockey team at the upcoming Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. The two countries held talks at the demilitarized zone (DMZ) and agreed on various joint activities, including training sessions for skiers and a cultural event at Mount Kumgang. North Korea will send around 230 supporters to cheer on its athletes, with a smaller delegation attending the Paralympics.

The International Olympics Committee (IOC) is currently evaluating the proposals, with the joint hockey team being the most complicated due to competition-related issues. The thaw in relations comes after years of broken communications and heightened tensions over North Korea's nuclear weapons program and missile tests.

Some of South Korea's allies, such as Japan, have expressed concern that Pyongyang may be using the talks to buy time to continue its weapons development. The US military has also increased its presence in the region as a show of force. China, on the other hand, denounced the recent talks in Vancouver as demonstrating a "Cold War mentality."

The prospect of a unified ice hockey team has been met with mixed reactions in South Korea, with some athletes and citizens expressing concerns about losing their spots on the team. More than 100 petitions have been sent to South Korea's presidential Blue House website opposing the joint team.

Despite these challenges, both South and North Korea view the Olympics as an opportunity to show reconciliation and unity. The two countries are still technically at war, as the 1950-53 conflict ended in a truce, not a peace treaty. The Winter Olympics are set to begin early next month.

In the first incident, a man identified as James Dirk Crudup, 41, who is homeless, was apprehended by Secret Service officers after he climbed over the fence. In two separate incidents in January 2017, quick-thinking 911 dispatchers in Johnston County, North Carolina, helped save women from dangerous situations. In the first instance, a woman called 911 from a moving car, saying she was locked in the trunk by her jealous boyfriend. The call was hard to understand, and the woman was unable to provide clear information. 911 supervisor Tim Medlin, who received the call, was determined to help and came up with the idea to text the woman from the office's emergency cell phone. She responded, providing enough information for authorities to locate her and rescue her from the trunk. The woman's boyfriend, Nicholas Mattevi, was arrested and charged with false imprisonment.

In the second incident, a woman called 911 from a car trunk, saying she had been kidnapped from Raleigh and was traveling down the interstate. The call was lost before dispatchers could get any valuable information. Medlin, who was on duty, had an idea to use the office's emergency cell phone to text the woman. She responded, providing enough information for authorities to locate her and arrest her kidnapper, Mattevi, who was also charged with false imprisonment.

Both incidents highlight the importance of quick thinking and the use of technology in emergency situations. Jason Barbour, director of the Johnston County Emergency 911 Communications Center, praised Medlin's actions and expressed the need for 911 centers to be able to initiate texts from their systems. The women in both cases were found unharmed, and their kidnappers were arrested.

Lauren Bacall, the legendary Hollywood actress who died at the age of 89, left behind an estimated $26.6 million estate. In her will, filed last fall, she made provisions for her beloved dog, Sophie, leaving $10,000 to her son, Sam Robards, for the papillon's care. The majority of her estate was to be split among her three children: Leslie Bogart, Stephen Bogart, and Sam Robards. In a series of groundbreaking discoveries, scientists have uncovered evidence of advanced toolmaking and cultural behaviors in Africa during the Middle Stone Age, around 320,000 years ago. Previously, it was believed that modern behaviors such as symbolism, innovation, and art suddenly emerged during a "human revolution" 40-50,000 years ago. However, new research published in the journal Science challenges this view, revealing that these advanced behaviors occurred much earlier than thought.

At the Olorgesailie Basin in Kenya, researchers found distinct differences in stone tools from this period compared to older deposits in the area. Older sites yielded large, bulky stone tools such as hand axes and cleavers, while the new sites contained much smaller, standardized pieces such as points and blades. Many of these tools were made on obsidian, which came from great distances, indicating long-distance transport of raw materials.

The team also discovered bright red ochre pigment with evidence of grinding and cut marks, marking the earliest known pigments used to color rocks in the archaeological record. Together, the glass and ochre represent the earliest evidence for long-distance transport of raw materials in the East African record.

The Middle Stone Age is characterized by the absence or rarity of large cutting tools and the presence of prepared core technologies for making sophisticated points and blades. The transition between the African Early and Middle Stone Age occurred around the time that our own species, Homo sapiens, was evolving across the continent.

These discoveries suggest that one or more hominin groups were doing seemingly "modern" things at this critical time period, requiring an understanding of space and time and the transmission of technological skills through successive generations. The "human revolution" that made us modern never was, as archaeological evidence for modern behaviors arose much earlier.

However, more research is needed to understand the relationship between complex behaviors and hominin species from 500,000 years to 160,000 years ago when many species of hominins inhabited the African landscape. The gradual complex change is more difficult to interpret than revolution.

Meanwhile, Trump's running mate, Mike Pence, promised that Trump would offer "real specifics" on how to make the country safer in the coming days. Trump has been under fire for his comments about Second Amendment supporters and his false claim that President Barack Obama founded the Islamic State group.

Vice President Joe Biden, campaigning for Clinton, called Trump the most uninformed presidential nominee in history and argued that his erratic rhetoric would make Americans less safe. Biden also praised Clinton for offering solutions for the middle class on jobs and education and for building on the Obama administration's legacy.

Clinton's campaign launched a new effort to register voters among young, undocumented immigrants, who are prohibited from voting but have helped mobilize Latinos. The campaign hopes to capitalize on Trump's promises to deport them.

Separately, a New York Times investigation revealed that Trump's top adviser, Paul Manafort, has ties to a large network that Ukrainian government investigators say was used to loot assets and influence elections. Manafort's involvement in Russian and Ukrainian politics has previously been reported but has come under increased scrutiny as the U.S. election cycle focuses on the region.

Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski, who was fired after clashing with Manafort over campaign strategy, tweeted a link to the article and seemed to call out his successor. The media attention surrounding the article created a stir on social media, with many noting the awkwardness of the former Trump adviser's actions.

Nine-year-old Kieran Sorkin, born with a rare condition called microtia that left him without fully formed ears, underwent a groundbreaking procedure at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London to have a pair of ears created from his own ribs. Kieran, who is also deaf, has been able to hear with the help of several previous surgeries and a hearing aid. The procedure, led by consultant plastic and reconstructive surgeon Neil Bulstrode, was primarily cosmetic but brought significant psychological benefits for Kieran.

During the six-hour operation, Bulstrode harvested cartilage from both sides of Kieran's chest and shaped it into frameworks for his new ears. He used an outline of Kieran's mother's ears as a "family template" to ensure the best possible result. The ears were then grafted onto Kieran's head under pockets of skin and shaped using a vacuum to fit the contours of the new ears.

Kieran, who had struggled at school due to his appearance, was thrilled with the result and described it as a "wow" moment. His parents, David and Louise, were also overjoyed and described the procedure as a "major operation but a significant improvement in quality of life."

About 100 children in the UK are born without one or both ears each year. The psychological benefits of the procedure are significant, as it can greatly improve a child's confidence and performance at school.

Advances in tissue engineering mean that this kind of reconstructive surgery could be done differently in the future. Scientists at the University College London Institute for Child Health are creating stem cells from patients' fat tissue and inducing them to make cartilage or bone. This approach would be far less invasive for a child than the current method of harvesting rib cartilage.

Kieran will have a follow-up operation in six months to make his ears stand out from the scalp more, but he is already delighted with the result. His family is hopeful that future advances in tissue engineering will make the procedure even less invasive for children in need.

In the final days of the Obama administration, tensions between President Barack Obama and President-elect Donald Trump reached a new high. Trump accused Obama of putting "roadblocks" in his way during the transition process, a claim the White House declined to comment on. Trump's tweets came after Obama's caution against "demonizing those who are different" during a ceremony marking the Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor 75 years ago. Trump also expressed frustration over the Obama administration's actions related to Israel, including its refusal to veto a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements.

Meanwhile, Secretary of State John F. Kerry, who is preparing to leave office, confronts a mixed legacy. His greatest successes include the historic accord to curtail Iran's nuclear development program and the landmark climate change treaty to limit greenhouse gas emissions. However, his inability to halt the carnage in Syria or block Russia's growing influence, as well as his failure to end the Israeli-Palestinian standoff or stop Saudi Arabia from bombing civilians in Yemen, rank as serious blots on his record.

Trump and Obama had a "nice conversation" on Wednesday following Trump's tweets. Trump also announced that he will hold a press conference in early January, his first since the election. The Energy Department's decision not to comply with a request from the Trump transition team to provide names of employees who worked on the Obama administration's climate policy efforts also caused controversy. Despite disagreements during the campaign, Obama has committed to a peaceful and smooth transition of power and will attend Trump's inauguration on Jan. 20.

A Chinese villager, Guan Quanzhi, from Li Baizi village in the northwestern province of Gansu, received over $83,000 in compensation after being attacked by a wild panda last year. The incident occurred when local officials were trying to capture the animal, which wandered into the village. Guan was working on his land when the panda, chased by other villagers, entered his property and bit him in the leg. The attack required seven hours of surgery and left him with injuries that may necessitate further operations. The panda escaped after the attack. Guan's son sued local forestry officials and the Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve, which is home to over 100 wild pandas, for compensation. Following negotiations, the officials agreed to pay Guan 520,000 yuan.

Giant pandas, renowned for their lovable appearance, are members of the bear family and have a fearsome bite. They are under pressure from habitat loss and have a notoriously low reproductive rate. The number of wild pandas rose nearly 17 percent over the decade to 2013, reaching 1,864, according to a government survey. Pandas generate significant tourist revenue in several parts of China, including Beijing, which rents them to foreign zoos to capitalize on global fascination with the animals.

Despite their cuddly appearance, pandas can protect themselves as effectively as most other bears. They use their heavy weight, strong jaw muscles, and large molar teeth to defend themselves. However, attacks on humans are rare but can be severe. In 2008, a panda mauled a 20-year-old man who climbed into its enclosure at a zoo in southern China. The WWF cautions that a panda bite can be very nasty, although it is mainly used for crushing bamboo.

The Chinese government and conservation organizations are working to protect the giant panda population and mitigate human-panda conflicts. The incident involving Guan Quanzhi highlights the need for continued efforts to ensure the safety of both humans and pandas.

The Tennessee Bureau of Investigation (TBI) has issued an Amber Alert and is asking for the public's help in locating Carlie and Simpson. Authorities believe they may be in an isolated area, possibly in a campground or rural area.

The U.S. Marshals Service is also offering a $5,000 reward. Simpson is described as a balding, 5 feet 10 inches tall, 157-pound man with brown hair and brown eyes. He was last seen driving a white 2002 Dodge conversion van with Tennessee tag 173GPS.

Carlie is 4 feet 8 inches tall and weighs 75 pounds, with blond hair and blue eyes. She was last seen wearing a black and gray tank top with blue jeans. Anyone with information on Carlie or Simpson is asked to call the TBI at 1-800-824-3463 or the Rogersville Police Department at (423) 272-7555.

There have been rumors on social media that Simpson may be trying to protect Carlie, but TBI spokesperson Josh DeVine has clarified that this was not an innocent camping trip and that Carlie is in imminent danger of serious bodily harm or death. Authorities have received over 1,200 leads and are working with law enforcement in 19 states.

Carlie's mother, Shannon Trent, has expressed her concern for her daughter's safety and urged Simpson to come forward. She believes the alleged kidnapping was premeditated and that Simpson may have a lair or shelter. Simpson was once given custody of Carlie and her sister when their father, James, was having problems.

CBS News has announced major changes to the lineup of "The Early Show," effective January 3, 2011. The network is replacing co-hosts Harry Smith and Maggie Rodriguez, as well as weather forecaster Dave Price, with Chris Wragge and Erica Hill from the Saturday edition of the show, and Jeff Glor from the Saturday newscast. Marysol Castro, formerly of ABC's "Good Morning America" weekend edition, will join the team as the new weather anchor.

Smith, who had the longest tenure on "The Early Show," will stay at CBS as a news reporter and primary substitute at the "CBS Evening News," "Face the Nation," and "Sunday Morning." Rodriguez and Price's future roles at the network are still being determined.

The sudden changes come as CBS has consistently ranked third in the morning news ratings, behind NBC's "Today" show and ABC's "Good Morning America." CBS President Sean McManus expressed confidence in the new team, believing they will help the show grow.

The new team, Wragge and Hill, have proven their chemistry and adaptability on Saturday mornings, shifting between hard news and lighter fare. Smith, who had previously hosted a CBS morning show from 1987 to 1996, expressed gratitude for his time on the show and wished the new team success.

The changes were surprising to some, with veteran television critic David Bianculli commenting on the suddenness and potential desperation of the move. CBS is owned by CBS Corp.

Former President George H.W. Bush, who led the United States to a swift victory in the Persian Gulf War and oversaw the peaceful dissolution of the Soviet Union and unification of Germany, passed away on Friday at the age of 94. Bush, who was the last American president to serve in World War II, had a distinguished career before becoming Vice President under Ronald Reagan in 1980 and then succeeding him in the White House in 1988. He lost his bid for re-election to Democrat Bill Clinton in 1992, but later found vindication in the success of his eldest son, George W. Bush, who became president in 2000.

Bush was born in Milton, Massachusetts, and joined the Navy when World War II broke out, becoming its youngest pilot at the age of 18. He flew 58 missions in the Pacific and was shot down, but was rescued by a submarine. After the war, he married Barbara Pierce and finished his education at Yale, but chose to move to Texas to become a businessman instead of following his family's path to Wall Street. He co-founded Zapata Petroleum and later began his political career as chairman of the Harris County Republican Party.

Bush ran for the Senate in 1964 but was unsuccessful, and was then appointed as the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations by President Nixon. He went on to hold several other top appointments, including chairman of the Republican National Committee, envoy to China, and director of the CIA. Bush sought the presidency in 1980 and was the leading contender until being overshadowed by Reagan's tax-cut plans. He was eventually asked to be Reagan's running mate and served as a loyal vice president.

Bush's shining moment as vice president came after Reagan's assassination attempt in 1981, when he eased the crisis atmosphere without seeming to arrogate power to himself. He ran to succeed Reagan in 1988 and won the nomination, promising a "kinder and gentler nation" but also declaring "Read my lips: No new taxes." However, he abandoned this promise and signed a tax-raising measure, leading to a primary challenge from Pat Buchanan and eventual defeat by Clinton.

O.J. Simpson, the former football star and actor, is set to appear before the Nevada Parole Board on Thursday, September 30, in a hearing that could potentially grant him parole and release from Lovelock Correctional Center, where he has been serving a nine to 33-year sentence for armed robbery and other charges since 2008. Simpson, now 70, is currently serving his sentence for a botched 2007 burglary in a Las Vegas hotel, where he and a group of men attempted to recover memorabilia they believed belonged to him.

The media interest in the hearing is overwhelming, as Simpson was once a beloved figure in American culture, known for his football career, acting roles, and commercials. However, his fame was tarnished in 1994 when he was acquitted of the brutal stabbing deaths of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend, Ronald Goldman, in what became known as "the trial of the century." The public's opinions on the verdict were largely divided along racial lines, with many African-Americans believing the verdict was fair, while most whites thought Simpson had gotten away with murder.

In 1997, Simpson was found liable for the deaths of Brown and Goldman in a civil suit brought by their families and was ordered to pay $33.5 million in damages. Simpson's release from prison could potentially allow him to live on his NFL pension, which is estimated to be $25,000 per month, and is protected by law from being touched by the Brown and Goldman families to settle the judgment against him.

At his 2013 parole hearing, Simpson expressed remorse for the armed heist and told the parole board that he had been a model prisoner during his time in Lovelock. He also argued that the Las Vegas jury may have been dishing out payback for his 2007 book, "If I Did It," which detailed his version of the events leading up to the murders.

Jamaica's Parliament passed historic legislation on Tuesday, decriminalizing small amounts of marijuana and paving the way for a legal medical cannabis industry on the island. The new law makes possession of up to 2oz (56.6g) of marijuana a petty offense, eliminating the need for arrests and criminal records. Cultivation of up to five plants is also permitted. The legislation establishes a cannabis licensing authority to regulate cultivation, distribution, and use of marijuana for medical, scientific, and therapeutic purposes. Rastafarians can now legally use marijuana for religious purposes, and tourists with medical prescriptions can apply for permits to buy small amounts of "ganja."

The passage of this law marks a significant step in Jamaica's long-standing debate over relaxing marijuana laws. For decades, officials have been hesitant to decriminalize due to concerns about violating international treaties and potential sanctions from the US. However, recent changes in drug laws in other countries have emboldened Jamaican officials to explore the potential benefits of the nascent medical marijuana industry, health tourism, and innovative pot-derived items.

Marijuana has long been culturally entrenched in Jamaica, consumed as a medicinal herb, puffed as a sacrament by Rastafarians, and sung about in the island's famed reggae music. The new law is expected to generate revenue for the country, which is currently laboring under an IMF loan program.

The US assistant secretary for counter-narcotics affairs, William Brownfield, acknowledged Jamaica's sovereign decision but reminded the country of its international treaty obligations regarding drug trafficking and criminal organizations.

Jamaica is not alone in its efforts to ease marijuana restrictions. More than 20 US states allow some form of medical marijuana, and Colorado and Washington have legalized personal use. Uruguay became the first nation to create a legal marijuana market in 2014, and Argentina decriminalized personal possession under a 2009 supreme court ruling. Chile permits medical marijuana use.

AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed on December 28, 2014, killing all 162 people on board, has seen significant developments in the search and investigation process. The latest update came from Indonesian officials who reported finding four large objects on the ocean floor, believed to be parts of the missing plane. The largest object, measuring 18 meters long and 5.4 meters wide, is thought to be part of the jet's body.

The discovery came as Indonesian authorities announced that AirAsia did not have permission to fly on the day of the crash, as their operating license only permitted flights on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays. The airline's Surabaya to Singapore flights have been suspended as a result.

Search teams have recovered 30 bodies from the Java Sea, but the crucial voice and flight data recorders, known as the black boxes, have yet to be found. The cause of the crash remains unknown, but a 14-page report from Indonesia's Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency suggested that icing caused by bad weather may have damaged the Airbus A320's engines.

The search and rescue operation involves over 60 vessels and 20 aircraft, with strong currents and big waves making the recovery process challenging. The discovery of significant parts of the plane on the seabed is hoped to speed up the investigation and potentially help locate the black boxes.

Meanwhile, heart-wrenching stories have emerged from the families of the victims. One such story is that of Chiara Natasya Tanus, a 15-year-old Indonesian girl who lost her entire family in the crash. The family was on their way to visit her in Singapore for New Year's Eve.

The crash was the first fatal accident suffered by the AirAsia group, which began operations in 2001 and quickly became one of the region's most popular low-cost carriers. The investigation into the cause of the crash is ongoing.

Title: Internet Archive's "No More 404" Initiative: Preserving the Web's History and Fixing Broken Links

The Internet Archive, a non-profit organization dedicated to digitizing and archiving various forms of media, has launched an ambitious new project aimed at preserving the web's history and fixing broken links. This initiative, known as "No More 404," involves regular crawls of websites to archive pages as they are created and archive the pages they refer to (Passage 1).

When pages are changed or removed from the web, the Internet Archive hopes that links to the archived versions will replace broken links or serve as companion links, allowing users to view the original intended content. The ultimate goal is to eliminate broken links on the web, ensuring a more seamless and informative browsing experience for users.

Supported websites under the "No More 404" program will undergo regular crawls, with the archived pages being accessible through the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine. This not only preserves the history of the web but also ensures that users can access the content as it was originally intended by the page's authors.

In summary, the Internet Archive's "No More 404" initiative is a significant step towards preserving the web's history and improving the user experience by fixing broken links. Through regular crawls and archiving of web pages, the organization aims to ensure that the web remains an accessible and informative resource for all.

In recent news, the legal principle of habeas corpus, which ensures individuals cannot be held indefinitely without cause, has been in the spotlight. The first passage discusses the historical significance of habeas corpus, its enshrining in the US Constitution, and its erosion through the Military Commissions Act of 2006, which revoked the right for detainees at Guantánamo Bay and elsewhere to challenge their detention. The second passage reports on a groundbreaking decision in New York, where a judge granted a writ of habeas corpus to two research chimpanzees, Hercules and Leo, held at Stony Brook University. This marks the first time an animal has been granted this right, potentially leading to their release and setting a precedent for other captive animals. Despite this victory, the Nonhuman Rights Project, which filed the case, acknowledges that more legal arguments are needed before a definitive ruling on the chimpanzees' legal personhood can be made. Meanwhile, the habeas corpus rights of Guantánamo detainees continue to be contested, with the Supreme Court set to hear their cases once more. These developments highlight the ongoing debates surrounding the application of habeas corpus to various contexts and the implications for individual rights and freedoms.

Early Thursday morning on the Las Vegas Strip, a deadly and violent incident occurred when someone in a black Range Rover opened fire on a Maserati, causing it to crash into a taxi cab that burst into flames, leaving three people dead and at least six injured. The shooting is believed to have stemmed from an altercation at an unspecified casino resort. The Maserati driver, identified as Kenneth Wayne Cherry Jr., and the taxi driver, Michael Boldon, were both killed at the scene. The Maserati passenger and a taxi passenger were taken to the hospital with injuries.

The Range Rover, which had tinted windows, black custom rims, and paper dealer ads instead of license plates, fled the scene and was last seen near the Venetian resort as it headed north on Las Vegas Boulevard. Witnesses reported seeing the vehicles coming from the nearby CityCenter area. Police are contacting authorities in three neighboring states to be on the lookout for the SUV.

The shooting caused significant disruptions in the area, with Las Vegas Boulevard near Flamingo Road shut down and likely to remain closed for hours. Tourists and workers were affected by the traffic snarls and closures.

The incident marks the latest violence on the Strip since the beginning of the year, following two other incidents where people were critically wounded in a shooting at a parking garage and a tourist was stabbed in an elevator at The Hotel at Mandalay Bay.

Authorities are still investigating the genesis of the altercation and the motive behind the shooting. The passenger in the Maserati is being interviewed by detectives. The Range Rover is believed to have had multiple people inside, but it is not yet clear if there was any relationship or ill will between the people in the two vehicles beyond the argument at the valet station.

The Professional Drivers Association, a taxi driver organization, plans to donate $5,000 to the Boldon family. The association has donated thousands of dollars to drivers who have been robbed and assaulted on the job and their families since 2004.

Las Vegas, which prides itself on being safe for visitors, has seen several violent incidents in recent weeks but police have made arrests or identified suspects in each case. "People don't have to worry," said Metro spokesman

A teenage girl, Autumn Veatch, survived a small-plane crash in the North Cascades of Washington state and hiked for several days to reach safety, while the fate of her two step-grandparents, Leland and Sharon Bowman, remained uncertain. Autumn, a Bellingham High School student, was traveling with her step-grandparents from Kalispell, Montana, to Lynden, Washington, when their Beech A-35 went down. Authorities narrowed down the search area based on cellphone data and typical flight patterns but had not found the plane or its occupants until Autumn emerged from the wilderness.

Autumn was picked up by a motorist and taken to a hospital in Brewster for treatment of minor injuries and dehydration. Her father, David Veatch, was overjoyed to hear the news of her survival but expressed concern for the wellbeing of his step-in-laws. Autumn told her father that the plane crashed and caught fire after flying into a bank of clouds. She remained at the scene for a day before deciding to hike down and follow a trail to the trailhead on Highway 20.

Five aircraft and ground crews searched for the wreckage, aided by Autumn's description of the crash site. The search was suspended for the night, with Navy helicopters continuing the effort. The plane had last been detected on radar near Omak, Washington, about an hour after crossing the Idaho-Washington border. The last phone signal from one of the occupants was detected around 3:50 p.m.

Autumn's survival was celebrated, but the focus quickly returned to finding the wreckage and the other two occupants. Lt. Col. Jeffrey Lustick of the Civil Air Patrol expressed his joy at the moment but acknowledged the importance of continuing the search efforts. The incident marked a rare moment of joy in Lustick's 30-year career in the Civil Air Patrol and search-and-rescue.

In recent news, Gibson Guitar Corporation in Tennessee faced a raid by the Justice Department over allegations of trafficking in illegally obtained wood, a violation of the Lacey Act. The Lacey Act, a century-old endangered species law amended in 2008 to include plants, requires end users of endangered wood to certify the legality of their supply chain all the way to the trees. Gibson, however, denies these allegations and maintains that all of its purchases from Madagascar have complied with U.S. and Malagasy law.

Meanwhile, Alexa Internet has been donating their crawl data to the Internet Archive since 1996. These data are added to the Wayback Machine after an embargo period.

In the music industry, the Lacey Act has caused concern among guitar builders due to its retroactive nature. They are worried they might be forced to prove the provenance of wood they acquired decades ago. Attorney Ronald Bienstock has warned clients to be wary of traveling abroad with old guitars, as the law also covers the trade in vintage instruments.

The Gibson raids have raised questions about the responsibility of companies to ensure the legality of their supply chains and the government's role in enforcing environmental regulations. The intent of the Lacey Act is to reduce illegal logging and send a signal to the markets to source wood in a responsible way. The outcome of the Gibson case may provide clarity on what constitutes responsible sourcing.

In other news, Alexa Internet's daily crawl data have been donated to the Internet Archive since 1996, contributing to the Wayback Machine.

The violence began in earnest on Wednesday when Israel killed the top military commander of Hamas in a targeted airstrike. In response, Hamas ramped up its rocket attacks on Israel, including one that narrowly missed Tel Aviv.

Israel has now struck over 250 targets in the Gaza Strip and reported that around 300 rockets have been fired at Israel since the conflict began. The country's Iron Dome missile defense system has knocked 105 of those rockets out of the sky. Three Israeli civilians and three soldiers have been killed in the conflict, while 19 Palestinians and over 200 have been wounded.

Egypt, which has close ties to Hamas, has ordered its prime minister to lead a delegation into Gaza in an attempt to mediate a truce. The visit poses a challenge to Israel, which may be forced to scale back its military operations while the delegation is there. Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi, a top leader in the Muslim Brotherhood, has taken a more activist approach to Israeli-Palestinian violence than his predecessor, Hosni Mubarak.

The United States has been in contact with leaders of Israel and Egypt, supporting Israel's operation while pressing the Egyptians to rein in Hamas. President Barack Obama and administration officials have urged Hamas to stop its rocket attacks.

The conflict has strained Israel's relationship with Egypt, which forms the cornerstone of U.S. policy in the region. The outcome of the situation rests largely with Israel and Egypt, and the course of the conflict from here on out remains uncertain. Many Palestinians are hoping for support from the Arab world, which has largely passed them by during the Arab Spring.

Both sides have suffered casualties and damage, and many residents in southern Israel and in Gaza have hunkered down indoors, sheltering from airstrikes and rockets. In the small town of Hope, Maine, two residents had encounters with rabid animals within a week of each other. Rachel Borch, a 21-year-old woman, was jogging on a wooded trail near her home when she came across a rabid raccoon. The animal charged at her, baring its teeth, and she knew instantly that it was rabid. Borch tried to defend herself but was unable to run past the raccoon due to the narrow path. With adrenaline pumping, she suspended her disbelief and decided to use her hands to hold the animal down, believing she would have the greatest ability to defend herself. The raccoon latched onto her thumb and wouldn't let go, scratching her arms and legs wildly. Borch remembered seeing a puddle on the ground and quickly dragged the still biting raccoon into it, holding its head underwater until it stopped struggling. Borch was then taken to Pen Bay Medical Center for treatment and later confirmed that the raccoon had tested positive for rabies.

In a separate incident, a Wiscasset man was bitten on both hands by what was believed to be a rabid fox. The Maine CDC reported that as of June 7, there had been 20 animals, including raccoons, red foxes, and skunks, that had tested positive for rabies in 2017. In comparison, 64 animals had tested positive for rabies in Maine in 2016. Heidi Blood, the Hope Animal Control Officer, warned that if one animal tests positive for rabies, it's "almost 100 percent" certain there are other animals in the area also infected. Blood also reminded people and their pets to avoid such animals, even dead ones, as the rabies virus can live outside the body for 24 hours. Under Maine law, cats and dogs, even if they stay indoors, must be vaccinated against the disease. Borch is expected to receive the last of four rabies shots on Saturday and has been taking antibiotics for the puncture wounds on her hands.

These incidents serve as a reminder of the importance of being aware of rabies and taking precautions to protect oneself and pets from infected animals.

A team of scientists, including those from NASA and the European Southern Observatory (ESO), have made significant discoveries about Mars' ancient water history. According to the first passage, they found strong isotopic anomalies and high deuterium enrichment in Martian water, indicating that early Mars had a global equivalent water layer at least 137 meters deep. Passage 2 reveals that nearly half of the northern hemisphere of Mars was once covered by a massive ancient ocean, which was a mile deep in places and held 20 million cubic kilometres of water. This evidence, published in the journal Science, challenges the previous belief that water was an erratic presence on Mars and suggests that it was a warm and wet world in its youth.

The scientists used data from three powerful infrared telescopes - Keck II, Nasa's Infrared Telescope Facility, and the ESO's Very Large Telescope - to make maps of the Martian atmosphere over six years. They looked at how different forms of water molecules in the Martian air varied from place to place over the changing seasons. Martian water contains both standard water molecules and deuterium, a heavy isotope of hydrogen. When normal water is lost on Mars, the concentration of deuterium in the remaining water increases, allowing scientists to infer how much water there once was.

The infrared maps show that water near the Martian ice caps is enriched with deuterium, indicating that Mars must have lost a vast amount of water in the past. This discovery suggests that Mars had a global ocean that covered the entire surface to a depth of 137 meters. However, it is believed that the water pooled into a much deeper ocean in the low-lying northern plains, covering nearly a fifth of the planet's surface.

These findings add to the growing evidence that Mars was once a habitable planet, potentially capable of supporting life. The European Space Agency's Exomars rover, set to launch in 2018, will continue the search for chemical signatures of life on Mars. Four years ago, Swedish chemistry professor Charlotta Turner received a distressing text message from her doctoral student Firas Jumaah. Jumaah, a member of the ethno-religious group Yazidi, was hiding with his family in a disused bleach factory in Iraq as Isis fighters roamed the town. Jumaah had returned to Iraq for a family wedding but stayed behind to complete his lab work at Lund University. When violence broke out, he tried to go back to Sweden but was unable to due to closed borders and advancing Isis forces.

Turner was shocked and angered by the situation and contacted the university's then security chief Per Gustafson. With the university's global transport and security deal, Gustafson hired a security company to arrange a rescue operation. A few days later, two Landcruisers carrying four heavily-armed mercenaries arrived and safely transported Jumaah, his wife, and their two small children to Erbil Airport.

The news of this unique event spread, with Jumaah telling Lund's University Magazine that he felt both privileged and like a coward for leaving his mother and sisters behind. Fortunately, the rest of Jumaah's family survived the Isis occupation. Jumaah returned to Sweden to complete his PhD and now works for a pharmaceuticals company in Malmö. The family is almost finished paying the university back for the rescue operation.

In a separate report by NBC News, it was detailed that Jumaah's family had traveled to Iraq for a wedding when violence broke out, and Isis conducted a deadly offensive in northern Iraq, massacring and enslaving thousands of Yazidis. Jumaah had initially planned to go in and bring his family back to Sweden but was unable to due to closed borders and advancing Isis forces. Turner, who was contacted by Jumaah in a desperate situation, started looking for ways to rescue the family and approached the university's security chief who found a company to go in with armed men and rescue Jumaah and his family.

In recent news, Pippa Middleton, the younger sister of Kate Middleton, found herself at the center of controversy after being photographed in Paris with a man brandishing a gun at a paparazzi following their car. The incident occurred hours after Pippa attended an 18th century-themed party thrown by her close friend, French aristocrat and designer Vicomte Arthur de Soultrait.

The gun, which was pointed directly at a photographer, raised concerns as France is currently on a heightened security alert after a string of fatal shootings. It is not clear whether the pistol was real or a fake, but the French authorities are investigating the incident after receiving a complaint from a member of the public.

Pippa, who was in the front seat of the car, is expected to be questioned by police and could be called as a witness if they decide to prosecute. The crime itself carries a maximum seven-year jail sentence.

The party, which saw costume-clad socialites greeted by three dwarves and concluded with a stripper bursting out of a giant birthday cake before disrobing to a remix of God Save The Queen, was described as decadent and filled with 'feathers, baubles, jewels and privileged youngsters'.

The PS4 is expected to be released "Holiday 2013," but the cost and final design have yet to be announced. Overall, the PS4 represents an improvement upon the PS3, with faster processing, prettier graphics, and a focus on the gaming experience.

In a groundbreaking development, scientists from the University of California, Berkeley have managed to reconstruct YouTube videos based on brain activity, offering a glimpse into the world of internal imagery and potentially paving the way for understanding dreams, memories, and even fantasies. The researchers, led by Jack Gallant, used functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) to measure subtle changes in blood flow to the visual areas of the brain as subjects watched YouTube videos. They then developed a computer model that matched features of the videos, such as colors, shapes, and movements, with patterns of brain activity.

The team was able to reconstruct the videos, albeit in a blurry and dream-like manner, by running the brain activity data backwards through the model. This technology could one day be used to broadcast imagery, allowing us to see the scenes that play out inside our minds independent from vision. Gallant believes that if they can decode the movies people saw, they might be able to decode things in the brain that are movie-like but have no real-world analog, like dreams.

The researchers acknowledge that this is just the beginning, and they hope to look at more visual modules in the brain to build better models and achieve higher resolution. They also need really big computers to process the vast amounts of data. Shinji Nishimoto, the study's lead author, stated that this research sheds light on how the brain understands and processes visual experiences.

The potential applications of this technology are vast and intriguing. It could potentially be used to help people who are paralyzed to control their environment by imagining sequences of movements. Brain waves recorded through electrodes on the scalp can already flip a switch, allowing communication. However, the ethical implications of being able to watch a person's memories or even their thoughts are complex and raise many questions.

The researchers were also asked about the potential use of this technology in detective work or court cases, but they emphasized that the accuracy of reading faulty memories only provides misleading information. The technology is still in its infancy, and further research is needed to understand its full potential and implications.

In Washington D.C., the House of Representatives returned from a week-long recess on Monday, with only a few items on the agenda before another planned recess and the potential government shutdown at the end of March. The most pressing matter was the implementation of the sequester, automatic spending cuts set to take effect on Friday, March 1.

President Obama has been advocating for a deal to replace the sequester with a combination of tax increases and alternative spending cuts. However, House Republicans, led by Speaker John Boehner, have embraced the sequester and are refusing to consider any deal that includes tax increases. Boehner instructed Obama to work with Senate Democrats to find a solution.

Meanwhile, the House spent much of its day engaging in time-wasting tactics, such as a roll-call vote on approving the journal of proceedings and speeches on unrelated topics. The chamber also passed a bill to rename the Neil A. Armstrong Flight Research Center at NASA, a proposal that had previously passed in the last Congress but had not been taken up by the Senate.

Despite the looming sequester and potential government shutdown, some politicians and pundits have downplayed the significance of the cuts, comparing them to past disasters and suggesting that Congress would find a way to avoid the worst consequences. The sequester is set to affect a wide range of government programs, including border security, airport security, Head Start, public housing support, NASA, special education, the FBI, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. However, the salaries of senators and representatives are not affected by the sequester.

Critics argue that members of Congress are not truly affected by the sequester and will find ways to insulate themselves from its consequences. Meanwhile, congressional staffers and other government employees face the possibility of furloughs and pay cuts.

In summary, the House of Representatives returned from recess on Monday with only a few items on the agenda before another planned recess and the potential government shutdown at the end of March. The most pressing matter was the implementation of the sequester, automatic spending cuts set to take effect on Friday, March 1. Despite the looming cuts, some politicians and pundits have downplayed their significance, suggesting that Congress would find a way to avoid the worst consequences.

Senator Elizabeth Warren called for the criminal investigation of Wells Fargo executives, including CEO John Stumpf, over the cross-selling scandal that led to the creation of millions of fake accounts. Warren accused Stumpf of failing to hold himself and other senior executives accountable for the company's actions and demanded his resignation and the return of his earnings. During the Senate hearing, Warren accused Stumpf of prioritizing cross-selling to drive up stock prices and enrich himself, while employees were pressured to meet quotas and cheated customers. Stumpf denied the allegations, stating that cross-selling was about deepening relationships. Warren, who has not received any donations from Wells Fargo's political action committee, criticized the culture that allowed the scandal to occur and compared it to theft.

Meanwhile, Donald Trump is expected to announce the recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital on Wednesday, a decision that has been met with criticism from various parties. The Pope called on the US to respect the status quo in Jerusalem, and the Palestinians warned that the recognition would be the "kiss of death" to the peace process. Violent protests are expected in response. The decision comes amidst a broader shift in Middle East politics, with Saudi Arabia presenting a peace plan that would be more favorable to Israel, making it increasingly doubtful that Trump will uphold his previous pledge to be a fair broker in negotiations between Israel and Palestine.

A hacker going by the name "thedarkoverlord" has claimed responsibility for stealing and leaking the upcoming season of Netflix's popular original series "Orange Is the New Black." The hacker obtained the first 10 episodes of season 5, which were released online before the scheduled June 9 premiere. The hack appears to have originated from a breach at post-production studio Larson Studios in late 2016. In addition to "Orange Is the New Black," the hacker also claims to have stolen unreleased shows from ABC, Fox, National Geographic, and IFC.

Netflix confirmed the breach and described it as an "active situation" being investigated by the FBI and other authorities. The company did not comment on the authenticity of the leaked episodes or the hacker's demands. The hacker has reportedly made extortion demands to Netflix, asking for an unspecified sum of money to prevent further leaks. However, it's unclear whether the motive for the hack is financial gain or bragging rights in the cybercrime underworld.

The hack could have significant consequences for Netflix. The company is counting on "Orange Is the New Black" to help it add 3.2 million subscribers from April through June, a substantial increase from its average gain in the same period over the past five years. A dip in subscriber growth could negatively impact Netflix's stock price.

Rumors of a massive leak of Hollywood films and TV episodes have been circulating online for months, with purported screenshots and a copy of a proposed deal to delete the stolen material in return for tens of thousands of dollars in electronic currency. It's not clear what triggered the hacker's renewed ransom demands.

Actress Laverne Cox, who stars in "Orange Is the New Black," attended the FYC Screening for the show at DGA Theater in New York in August 2015. (Associated Press)

Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared on March 8, 2014, continues to baffle investigators, with statistical tools providing no definitive answers about its location or cause. However, Bayesian statistics, a method named after 18th century Presbyterian minister Thomas Bayes, can help refine and focus the search by allowing hunters to update their estimates of the probability of finding the plane based on new information.

In 2009, Bayesian statistics were used to locate the wreckage of Air France Flight 447, which had gone missing for two years. The method allows assessing various scenarios, even contradictory ones, and combining them to find the most likely solution. It also allows updating the model with new information.

The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 is complicated by the fact that it is believed to have been deliberately diverted, making spots farther from the takeoff point in Kuala Lumpur more likely. Bayesian inference formalizes common sense and helps update probabilities based on new information.

Thomas Bayes was a British Presbyterian minister born in London in 1702. He studied logic and theology at the University of Edinburgh and became a minister in a Presbyterian chapel. He is best known for his mathematical work on probability, which gave rise to Bayes' Theorem. Bayesian probability estimates are used all over the world, built into software that forecasts events including financial markets and weather. He died in Royal Tunbridge Wells in 1761.

The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 is ongoing, with a large area in the Indian Ocean being searched. The probability map provided by Bayesian statisticians has given investigators a much tighter area to search, but so far, no sign of the plane has been found. The mystery of the crash may never be solved, as it is very likely that the plane is at the bottom of the Indian Ocean and will never be found.

Even finding debris might not be helpful, as it could take a long time for the wreckage to surface, and it might not provide much information about the location of the bulk of the plane. The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 continues, with investigators hoping for a breakthrough.

In Damascus, Syria, twin blasts targeting the army command headquarters caused hours of sporadic gunbattles and a raging fire inside the heavily guarded compound, according to state-run media and witnesses. The explosions, which were heard several miles away and shattered windows of nearby buildings, were caused by a car bomb and an explosive device near the army command buildings, according to an army statement. One Syrian national and correspondent for Iranian Press TV, Maya Nasser, was killed in an exchange of fire following the blasts. The British-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported heavy clashes inside the compound of the army command, with casualties on both sides. Witnesses said rebels may have been holed up inside the army command building. The explosions were the latest in a series of attacks on security sites and symbols of regime power in Syria, which has been embroiled in a civil war for over a year. The conflict, which began in March 2011 with protests calling for political change, has killed nearly 30,000 people according to activists. In July, rebels penetrated the heart of Syria's power elite, detonating a bomb inside a high-level crisis meeting in Damascus that killed three top regime officials. General Assembly's annual meeting in New York this week, with U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon demanding international action to stop the war and calling it a serious and growing threat to international peace and security. However, the U.N.'s most powerful body, the Security Council, has been paralyzed due to deep divisions and Russia and China's vetoes of Western-backed resolutions aimed at pressuring Assad to end the violence and enter negotiations on a political transition. In contrast, President Barack Obama pledged U.S. support for Syrians trying to oust Assad, who he called a dictator who massacres his own people. A grisly discovery was made in Lancaster, California, when a decomposing body was found inside a supermarket entrance column. The incident occurred at a WinCo Foods store on the 700 block of West Avenue K, where the manager reported a strong odor coming from the column on Saturday afternoon. A plumber and handyman were called to investigate, and upon breaking off some bricks, they discovered a leg and shoe inside.

The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department's homicide detectives arrived at the scene and identified the body as that of a man believed to be a chase suspect who had eluded authorities earlier in the week. The suspect had led deputies on a foot chase on Monday, which ended in a crash. He then managed to escape by running into the supermarket and onto the roof.

Detectives believe the suspect may have tried to hide from the deputies by getting inside the column but was unable to get out. An autopsy is pending to determine the exact cause of death, and it's unclear whether the victim fell to his death or became trapped and couldn't get out.

The store was closed as the investigation continued, and crews worked to extract the body. The coroner's office later identified the man as Raymundo Rivera, 35. Witnesses reported seeing the suspect run into the store and get onto the roof before disappearing.

The discovery was a shock to investigators, with some expressing disbelief at the thought of being trapped inside the column in the extreme heat. Anyone with information regarding the incident was encouraged to contact the LASD Homicide Bureau at (323) 890-5500 or "Crime Stoppers" at (800) 222-TIPS (8477).
