Robert Durst, a New York real estate heir and celebrity murder suspect, was sentenced to seven years in prison on a weapons charge in New Orleans on April 27, 2016. Durst, who appeared frail in court, had pleaded guilty to the charge in February and requested to serve his time in a low-security federal prison in Los Angeles while awaiting trial for the 2000 murder of his friend Susan Berman. Durst's attorneys cited his advanced age and poor health in their request for him to be housed at FCI Terminal Island, a federal prison with medical facilities near Los Angeles.

Durst, 73, had been held in Louisiana since his March 2015 arrest on a charge of being a felon in possession of a firearm. His arrest came one day before the series finale of an HBO documentary entitled, “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst,” which chronicled several police investigations of Durst in connection with the dismemberment killing of a male neighbor in Texas in 2003, the disappearance of his wife, Kathleen, in New York in 1982, and Berman's death. In the series’ final episode, Durst’s voice was captured on a microphone after an interview as he muttered that he had “killed them all.”

Durst has previous convictions in Texas related to jumping bail and carrying a weapon across state lines in 2004 as he tried to flee the murder prosecution there. He served about three years in connection with those charges. Prosecutors say Durst, who has long been estranged from his family, is worth some $100 million. Durst could move to California within four to six weeks, his attorney Dick DeGuerin said before Wednesday’s hearing. He was expected to be arraigned on the murder charge in Los Angeles on August 18.

The gun charge stemmed from a search of Durst’s hotel room on March 14, 2015, which turned up a flesh-colored latex mask with salt-and-pepper hair, five ounces of marijuana, more than $100,000 in cash and a loaded Smith and Wesson .38-caliber revolver, authorities said. Dur

The Benghazi attack of 2012, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans, has been the subject of extensive investigation by various government bodies. The final report of the House Benghazi Select Committee, released on Tuesday, revealed new details about the events leading up to and during the attack. According to the report, State Department officials had concerns about Marines potentially wearing uniforms during the attack due to the potential diplomatic implications. However, this issue did not affect the response time of the military.

The report also found that the Obama administration provided conflicting public and private statements about the attack in its aftermath. For instance, while Secretary Clinton publicly blamed the attack on a protest and an inflammatory video, her private communications and conversations with foreign leaders indicated that she knew the attack was a terrorist assault.

The report also criticized Clinton and other officials for not adequately addressing growing extremism in Libya before the attack. Additionally, the report accused Clinton of falsely blaming the violence on the video to deflect attention from the administration's failure to protect American diplomats.

Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.), the ranking Democrat on the committee, expressed disappointment with the partisan nature of the investigation and the lack of transparency. He accused the panel's chairman, Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.), of withholding information from Democrats and preventing accountability.

The report's release comes after Democrats on the committee released their rebuttal to the GOP report on Monday. They argued that the investigation was a waste of taxpayer funds and that the findings did not alter the public's understanding of the attack.

In other news, the Internet Archive announced its efforts to archive web pages and preserve links to ensure that broken links on the web are fixed. The organization aims to provide access to the original intended content of web pages, even if the pages are later changed or removed.

Overall, the Benghazi attack and its aftermath continue to be a source of controversy and political debate, with both parties accusing each other of misrepresenting the facts and withholding information.

In Charlottesville, Virginia, a pretrial hearing was held on Monday for Jesse LeRoy Matthew Jr., who is charged with capital murder in the 2014 disappearance and death of University of Virginia student Hannah Graham. Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty, and Matthew also faces first-degree murder charges in the 2009 death of Virginia Tech student Morgan Harrington.

During the hearing, former Louisa County Sheriff's Office Detective Buck Garner testified about his involvement in the early days of the Graham investigation. He described following his bloodhound, Shaker, as it traced Graham's scent to Charlottesville's downtown area, where she was last seen. Surveillance video from businesses showed Graham walking alongside Matthew. Her remains were found six weeks later on an abandoned property in Albemarle County.

Garner testified that Shaker detected Graham's scent at an industrial site about a mile from downtown Charlottesville. The dog alerted him to a scent indicating "fear and adrenaline," suggesting that Graham may have been attacked near a mulch pile at the site. The dog also found Graham's scent on the passenger door of Matthew's vehicle, in the doorway to his home, and near a dumpster at his apartment complex.

Defense attorney Doug Ramseur unsuccessfully challenged the search warrant for Matthew's apartment and vehicle, arguing that the search dog's findings were inconsistent with witness accounts and video surveillance evidence, that detectives might have misled a magistrate to obtain the warrant, and that there was not probable cause for police to conduct those searches.

Albemarle County Circuit Judge Cheryl Higgins ruled that there were no "instances of deliberate misstatements and reckless disregard" of the truth in the affidavit supporting the search warrant. She noted that witness statements put Graham and Matthew together on the night of her disappearance, at least one witness said they saw the two go to a bar on the Downtown Mall, and Matthew bought them each drinks using his debit card.

Matthew is currently serving a life prison term for a 2005 attempted murder and sexual assault in northern Virginia.

Shannon Egeland, a convicted white-collar criminal, was sentenced to an extended prison term on July 28, 2021, for persuading his son to shoot him in the leg as part of a staged insurance scam just a day before he was to begin serving a decade-long federal prison sentence for mortgage fraud. Egeland, who stood on a prosthetic leg during the hearing, had previously pleaded guilty to fraud charges in the Desert Sun housing scandal in 2009. In the latest case, he had directed his son, Rylan Egeland, then 17, to shoot him in the legs with a shotgun on July 31, 2014, in an attempt to delay his prison sentence and benefit from a bogus disability insurance policy. Egeland had applied for the policy seven days earlier, falsely claiming he had never been arrested or indicted for a felony or misdemeanor in the prior 10 years.

The shooting was quickly detected, and Egeland was charged with conspiracy to commit wire fraud and interstate failure to pay child support. Prosecutors sought a five-year sentence for the insurance scam, while Egeland's lawyer urged a two-year sentence to be served consecutive to the 10-year sentence he was already serving. U.S. District Judge Anna J. Brown called Egeland's actions "an unthinkable kind of situation" and added three years and 10 months to his sentence.

Assistant U.S. Attorney Scott Bradford described Egeland as a "menace to society" and a "self-absorbed, opportunistic narcissist" motivated by greed who recklessly manipulated his son. The psychological and emotional destruction Egeland caused his son is "unimaginable," Bradford wrote in a sentencing memo. Egeland had his teenage son obtain a 20-gauge shotgun, while he got the ammunition and directed his son to shoot him in the legs.

Egeland had previously been accused of drug-related offenses and perjury while on pretrial release in the mortgage fraud case. He was convicted of both at trial but had the drug conviction overturned due to a jury instruction problem. In June 2013, he also pleaded guilty to theft for shopl

A fatal Tesla crash occurred on March 23, 2018, in Mountain View, California, leaving a 38-year-old Apple engineer named Walter Huang dead. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) and the California Highway Patrol (CHP) are currently investigating the accident. According to Tesla's statement, Autopilot was engaged with the adaptive cruise control follow-distance set to minimum when the collision happened. The driver had received several visual and audible warnings earlier in the drive, but his hands were not detected on the wheel for six seconds before the crash.

The crash was severe due to the crash attenuator, a highway safety barrier, being crushed in a prior accident without being replaced. Tesla stated that they had never seen this level of damage to a Model X in any other crash. Huang's brother, Will, claimed that Walter had complained "seven to 10 times" that the car would swerve toward the same barrier during Autopilot. He took the car to the dealership to address the issue, but they couldn't duplicate it.

The California Department of Transportation (CalTrans) released a statement saying that replacement work was scheduled for the damaged guardrail or crash attenuators. However, storms can delay the fix. The previous accident that damaged the barrier took place 11 days before Huang's fatal crash.

Autopilot and autonomous vehicles have come under increased scrutiny recently after a woman was killed by an Uber autonomous vehicle in Tempe, Arizona. Arizona's governor suspended Uber's license to test autonomous vehicles on public roads last week. Tesla, however, maintains that Autopilot "unequivocally makes the world safer for the vehicle occupants, pedestrians, and cyclists."

Huang was a caring guy, according to his friends and family. He had a wife and two kids, lived in Foster City, and worked for 13 years as a programmer at Electronic Arts before getting a job as an Apple engineer and buying a new Tesla. His friends are remembering his contributions to the gaming world and missing his friendship.

CalTrans and Tesla have not commented on the issue of the collapsed safety barrier that Huang hit. His friends are raising money for his wife and kids to handle the expenses of the funeral and life after his

Robin Williams, the beloved comedian and actor, passed away at the age of 63, with initial reports suggesting an apparent suicide by asphyxia. Williams, who was known for his edgy comedy and dramatic turns, had a profound impact on generations, particularly those in their mid-to-late 20s and early 30s. In the 1990s, Williams shifted his career towards entertaining children, taking on humble roles in animated films and family movies. His performance as the Genie in Disney's "Aladdin" was a triumph, lending the grimmer story its imaginative expansiveness. Williams' generosity and unselfishness in lowering himself to the level of kids resonated with audiences, leaving a lasting impact.

The author shares a personal connection to Williams, having met him as an unknown stand-up comedian in 1978. The encounter left a lasting impression on the author, with Williams' dazzling, complex, and brilliantly funny performance defying description. After the show, Williams and the author had a brief conversation about his impending fame, with Williams insisting that it wouldn't happen.

As Williams' career took off, he became a household name, but the author could never forget their encounter or the "Help me" moment from "The Fly" that Williams had shared with him. Williams' restlessness and search for experience and knowledge drove him to go into drama, taking on not only comic roles but also dark ones.

Despite his success, Williams struggled in the mid-2000s as mid-budget adult dramas began to disappear. His later projects, such as "Jakob the Liar" and "Bicentennial Man," had conceits that were two degrees removed from the sunny, high-concept optimism of kids' movies. However, for those who grew up with his movies, Williams remains a beloved figure, leaving a lasting impact on rec-room carpets as kids rewound his movies again and again.

A murder suspect, Jayveon Caballero, 29, is on the run following a fatal shooting in Montpelier, Vermont, which marked the city's first murder in almost a century. The victim, Markus Austin, 33, was shot outside his apartment early Sunday morning after an altercation outside Gusto's bar in Barre. Witnesses reported that Caballero and Austin had been friends and had been out together before the incident. During the altercation, Austin allegedly assaulted Caballero's girlfriend, Desiree Cary.

Caballero then confronted Austin outside his apartment and shot him. Police believe Caballero may have fled the state and are seeking information on his whereabouts. An arrest warrant has been issued for Caballero, and bail has been set at $500,000. Cary, who was the target of an ongoing drug investigation, was taken into custody following a motor vehicle stop in Barre. She has been held in custody for lack of $10,000 bail and faces charges of selling crack cocaine and heroin.

The shooting occurred at 191 Barre Street in Montpelier around 4:30 a.m. on Sunday. Police have since learned that Caballero and Austin knew each other and were involved in an altercation outside the Gustos bar on Prospect Street in Barre prior to the shooting. Several others were also involved in the altercation, and some have been interviewed by police.

Caballero's girlfriend, Cary, was taken into custody following a motor vehicle stop in Barre on Sunday evening. A search warrant was executed at Caballero's residence, 1099 South Barre Road in Barre, early Monday in an attempt to take him into custody. The Vermont State Police are asking anyone with information about Caballero's location or the shooting to contact them.

Montpelier, with a population of approximately 7,500, is the nation's least populous capital city. The shooting death of Austin is the first murder in the city since the 1920s, when a woman shot her husband.

On January 31, 2018, a unique astronomical event will take place: a Super Blue Blood-Moon Total Eclipse. This means that there will be a total lunar eclipse during a blue moon, which is the second full moon in a month. This phenomenon hasn't occurred for over 150 years. The eclipse will be visible from various parts of the world, including Central and Eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, most of Australia, and the Pacific Ocean. In the United States, Alaska, Hawaii, and northwestern Canada will have a clear view of the entire event, while the rest of North and Central America will only see the beginning or end of the eclipse due to moonset.

The Virtual Telescope Project, in partnership with several astrophotographers and Tenagra Observatories, will provide live streams of the eclipse for viewers. The first live stream will show the Supermoon rising above Rome, while the second will cover the total lunar eclipse itself. The online sessions are scheduled for 11:30 UT for the Supermoon rising above Rome and 16:00 UT for the total lunar eclipse.

The Super Blue Blood-Moon Total Eclipse is also a Supermoon, which means that the moon will appear 14% bigger and 30% brighter than regular full moons. The eclipse will cause the moon to take on a reddish hue due to the way the atmosphere bends the light. This is why totally eclipsed moons are sometimes called "blood moons."

Visible supermoons aren't very rare, but having three in a row is. The first supermoon appeared on December 3, 2017, and the second one will be on New Year's Day 2018. The third and final supermoon, which will also feature the total lunar eclipse, will occur on January 31, 2018.

To capture a picture of the supermoon or lunar eclipse, you can use a smartphone or a DSLR camera. In the past week, the embattled city of Hama in Syria has seen significant protests against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, resulting in numerous arrests, deaths, and the departure of thousands of residents in fear of further violence. On Thursday, the U.S. ambassador to Syria, Robert Ford, visited Hama to show solidarity with residents and express support for their right to peaceful demonstrations. The visit was met with a warm welcome from Hama residents, but was criticized by the Syrian government, which accused the U.S. of interfering in its affairs.

On Friday, activists reported that over 500,000 Syrians had gathered in Hama for the largest protest yet against the government, with an estimated 13 protesters killed in various cities across the country. The Syrian state-run TV blamed the deaths on snipers from "armed gangs," while activists claimed that security forces were responsible. Hama has become a symbol of resistance to injustice in Syria, with residents carrying olive branches during the peaceful demonstrations.

The visit by Ford and the French ambassador to Hama prompted accusations of interference from the Syrian government, which also reported that Syrian embassy staff in the U.S. had filmed anti-government protests. In response, the U.S. summoned the Syrian ambassador for talks to express concerns over the reported actions of the embassy staff.

Meanwhile, an estimated 1,000 Syrians have fled Hama due to fears of another military crackdown, with reports of at least 23 civilians killed and mass arrests in the nearby town of Salamiyah. The situation in Hama remains tense, with authorities urging demonstrators to avoid confrontations and clear the streets to allow residents to go to work.

Hama has a significant historical context in Syria, as it was the site of a brutal military crackdown on a revolt by the banned Muslim Brotherhood against then-president Hafez al-Assad in 1982, resulting in the deaths of at least 20,000 people. The city has continued to be a symbol of opposition to the current government.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation is currently investigating an attempted hack on the Democratic National Committee's (DNC) voter database. Initially, the DNC and its security partners believed they were dealing with a sophisticated cyberattack. However, upon further investigation, it was discovered that the attempt was actually a "simulated phishing test" rather than a genuine hack.

The DNC was alerted to the potential attack on Tuesday when a fake login page was detected. The page was designed to mimic the access page used by Democratic Party officials and campaigns to log into Votebuilder, the service that hosts the DNC's voter database. The DNC, along with its cloud service provider and security research firm, were able to thwart the potential attack.

This incident comes as political groups and government organizations are on high alert for new hacks and foreign meddling ahead of the midterm elections. The focus has shifted from using the cyber realm to steal secrets to using it to impose national power. In the past, Russia and other actors have targeted voter-registration systems and think tanks, demonstrating the vast opportunities for manipulation in the cyber age.

Microsoft recently reported that hackers tied to Russian intelligence targeted the Senate and conservative think tanks in the United States. Additionally, Facebook identified a political influence campaign aimed at potentially disrupting the midterms. The company also uncovered other disinformation efforts targeting people around the world.

Rob Joyce, the former White House cybersecurity coordinator, noted that the cyber realm is no longer just used for stealing secrets but is now being used to impose national power. The cyber age has changed elections forever, with many systems vulnerable to manipulation. The DNC incident serves as a reminder of the constant threats and the need to remain vigilant in order to prevent future attacks.

Boston Marathon Bombings: Three Victims Identified, City Grapples with Grief and Healing

Two days after the Boston Marathon bombings left three people dead and over 170 injured, the city was coming to terms with the tragedy while authorities continued their search for the perpetrators. Two of the victims have been identified: Martin Richard, 8, from Dorchester, and Krystle Campbell, 29, a restaurant manager from Medford.

Martin Richard was watching the race with his father when the explosions occurred. His mother and sister were also injured in the blasts. Obesity is a growing health concern worldwide, with nearly 30% of the global population, or 2.1 billion people, now considered overweight or obese, according to a new report published in the medical journal Lancet. The USA leads the world in obesity, with 87 million of the world's obese population, but the problem is not limited to developed countries. Obesity rates are rising in both rich and poor nations, with some countries, such as those in the Middle East and North Africa, Central America, and the Pacific and Caribbean islands, reaching staggeringly high levels. The biggest increases in obesity among women were seen in Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Honduras, and Bahrain, while among men, the biggest increases were in New Zealand, Bahrain, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, and the United States.

Obesity is a complex problem fueled by the availability of cheap, high-calorie junk food and sedentary lifestyles. It is a major risk factor for various health issues, including heart disease, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, and certain cancers, and chronic complications of weight kill about 3.4 million adults annually. During the 33-year period studied, rates of obesity and overweight soared 28% in adults and 47% in children.

The problem is not limited to rich nations, with two-thirds of the obese population residing in developing countries. The Middle East and North Africa region saw the highest obesity rates, with more than 58% of adult men and 65% of adult women overweight or obese. Obesity is appearing at increasingly young ages, with nearly 50% of the increase in children and adolescents worldwide.

The report notes that obesity is not just a cosmetic issue but a major risk factor for morbidity and mortality. The researchers called for a renewed focus on preventing and addressing obesity, particularly in developing countries where the problem is rapidly increasing. The World Health Organization has launched a commission to study rising obesity among children worldwide and suggest solutions.

Barry and Honey Sherman, the billionaire Canadian philanthropists and founders of Apotex Inc., were found dead in their Toronto mansion on Friday, December 15. The cause of their deaths was later determined to be "ligature neck compression," or strangulation, according to Toronto police. The investigation into their deaths is now being led by the homicide squad.

The couple, who had been married for over 50 years and had four children and a new grandchild, were discovered by their real estate agent. There were no signs of forced entry and no note left behind. Over the weekend, friends and colleagues paid tribute to the Shermans, describing them as kind, generous, and dedicated to their community.

Initially, police classified the deaths as "suspicious," but multiple media outlets reported that investigators were looking into the possibility of a murder-suicide. However, the Sherman family dismissed this theory, stating that their parents' lives were inconsistent with such rumors.

Barry Sherman, a renowned workaholic, founded Apotex in 1974 and had a net worth of $4.77 billion. Honey Sherman was a gregarious philanthropist whose causes ranged from higher education to health care to the Jewish community. The couple were planning a dinner party with friends later this month.

Friends and colleagues described Barry as a dedicated worker who loved what he did, and Honey as a dedicated philanthropist who always got her way. The couple were well-known in Toronto's Jewish community and had handed out millions of dollars to hospitals, universities, and various charities.

The news of their deaths shocked the community, with many expressing disbelief and sadness. Toronto Mayor John Tory and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau were among those who paid tribute to the Shermans. A makeshift memorial was set up outside their home, with flowers and condolences pouring in from the community.

The investigation into the Shermans' deaths is ongoing, with no suspects at large. Toronto police have asked anyone with information to come forward.

Egyptians continued voting in the third round of parliamentary elections on January 2, 2012, while former President Hosni Mubarak faced prosecution for "tyranny and violence" during his trial. The final stage of the vote covered nine provinces, including the North and South Sinai governorates, and was expected to consolidate the gains of Islamist groups, particularly the Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice party. The Brotherhood, Egypt's best-organized political force, was on track to win a clear majority of the seats in the full Parliament, which could enable them to govern without forming a coalition and reduce the power of ultraconservative Islamists and liberal parties.

Mubarak, who has pleaded not guilty to charges of corruption and conspiring to kill protesters, was on trial alongside his sons, Alaa and Gamal, and former Interior Minister Habib el-Adli. Prosecutor Mustafa Soliman accused Mubarak of imposing a "tyrannical rule" and devoting the last decade of his three-decade presidency to ensuring his son's succession. The trial, which began in August 2011, has been bogged down in procedural matters, including a demand to remove the presiding judge. Mubarak is charged with complicity in the killing of over 800 protesters during the anti-Mubarak uprising that forced him out of office on February 11, 2011. He could face the death penalty if convicted.

The military rulers, led by Field Marshal Mohamed Hussein Tantawi, have scheduled the first session of the lower house of Parliament for January 23, two days before the anniversary of the protests that ousted Mubarak. The Parliament is expected to take authority over the hiring and firing of a prime minister to run the interim government, but the military rulers have said they intend to retain that authority and allocate very little power to the Parliament.

On Wednesday evening in Mendon, a car driven by Nabila Altahan was suspended from a telephone guy wire after the driver reacted too quickly to her GPS unit's instructions to turn around. The incident occurred around 8 p.m. on Route 4, near Sugar & Spice Restaurant. According to police reports, Altahan had passed her intended destination when her GPS device suddenly gave directions to turn around. In response, Altahan quickly steered the Toyota Corolla off the road and up the wire support of a telephone pole.

Fortunately, Altahan and her passenger were not injured in the incident. A witness at a nearby miniature golf course reported seeing the driver jump out of the car as it was suspended from the pole. Emergency responders, including State Police and Rutland City Fire Department, arrived at the scene to assess the situation. The cause of the accident is under investigation, but it appears that the driver's overreaction to her GPS device's directions led to the car leaving the road and becoming entangled in the telephone wire.
